Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Differential Geometry in the Large" will take place July 11 to 15, 2016 in Florence, Italy. The grant covers travel expenses and hotel expenses for graduate students, postdocs, and senior mathematicians without other federal funding. Further local expenses are covered by Italian grants and funds from the University of Florenz. Participation by women and under represented minorities is actively sought and encouraged. The meeting will encourage interaction between recent Ph.D.'s based in the US and their Italian counterparts. Closer relationships will be formed between graduate students that could well lead to mathematical collaborations in the future.

The conference will provide an environment for American graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s in which they can learn about new developments in global Riemannian geometry, through research talks by international experts. The 4 topics selected, manifolds with lower curvature bounds, geometric flows, special geometries and min-max theory have been particularly productive over the last few years. The participants will also be given an opportunity to present their results through talks and poster sessions, enabling especially younger participants to initiate conversations with others.

Additional details can be found in the website: http://www.dma.unifi.it/~verdiani/dgl2016/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference "Differential Geometry In the Large" took place July 11 to July 15, 2016 in Florence, Italy. It was attended by 105 articipants, a large percentage consisted of graduate students and recent postdocs. 23 of the participants from the US received financial support for flight and hotel, more than half of which were graduate students based in the US, others being recent postdocs, and 4 senior mathematicians without their own grant support. The program, participants and speakers can be found on the homepage  www.dma.unifi.it/~verdiani/dgl2016/index.html.

Major themes of the talks consisted of:

Manifolds with lower curvature bounds, including sectional and Ricci curvature, geometric flows, in particular Ricci flow, Kaehler geometry and Kaehler Einstein metrics, minimal surfaces, homogeneous and curvature homogeneous manifolds.

Many of these talks  were survey talks introducing  young mathematicians to particularly active areas and discussed recent progress. The speakers were encouraged to discuss open problems as well. We organized a 2 hour problem session on the last day. A list of such problems can be found on the conference web page.

The meeting encouraged interaction between young mathematicians  based in the US and Italy. Ample time was left in between the talks in order to facilitate such encounters.  We were also able to support some underrepresented minorities with tavel and hotel expenses.

The conference was considered to be a great success with positive feedback, especially from young mathematicians.
